file_metadata.title: Vertically- and horizontally-transmitted memories – the fading boundaries between regeneration and inheritance in planaria
file_metadata.abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The Weismann barrier postulates that genetic information passes only from the germline to the soma and not in reverse, thus providing an obstacle to the inheritance of acquired traits. Certain organisms such as planaria – flatworms that can reproduce through asymmetric fission – avoid the limitations of this barrier, thus blurring the distinction between the processes of inheritance and development. In this paper, we re-evaluate canonical ideas about the interaction between developmental, genetic and evolutionary processes through the lens of planaria. Biased distribution of epigenetic effects in asymmetrically produced parts of a regenerating organism could increase variation and therefore affect the species' evolution. The maintenance and fixing of somatic experiences, encoded via stable biochemical or physiological states, may contribute to evolutionary processes in the absence of classically defined generations. We discuss different mechanisms that could induce asymmetry between the two organisms that eventually develop from the regenerating parts, including one particularly fascinating source – the potential capacity of the brain to produce long-lasting epigenetic changes.</jats:p>

chunks.text: The Weismann barrier separates germline and soma, preventing inheritance of acquired traits; however, planaria challenge this concept through asexual fission, blurring inheritance and development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria's asexual reproduction challenges the Weismann barrier by blurring the lines between inheritance and development.

chunks.text: Asymmetric distribution of epigenetic effects in regenerating planaria could increase variation and influence evolution, with somatic experiences potentially contributing to evolutionary processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Asymmetric epigenetic effects in regenerating planaria may drive evolutionary change by increasing variation and preserving somatic experiences.

chunks.text: Planarian regeneration challenges traditional evolutionary models based on Mendelian genetics and distinct generations, raising questions about the inheritance of acquired traits.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration challenges traditional evolutionary models based on Mendelian genetics by blurring generational boundaries.

chunks.text: Epigenetics necessitates a re-evaluation of traditional inheritance concepts, particularly in organisms with non-segregated germlines or asexual reproduction, where environmental influences may impact evolution.
chunks.chunk_summary: Epigenetics requires a reassessment of inheritance concepts, especially in organisms with non-segregated germlines or asexual reproduction.

chunks.text: Planaria, with their complex regeneration capabilities, serve as a model for studying stem cell regulation, morphogenesis, and physiological signaling, offering insights into inheritance and development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria's regenerative abilities make them a valuable model for studying stem cell regulation, morphogenesis, and physiological signaling.

chunks.text: Planarian fission and regeneration challenge the concept of distinct generations, raising questions about the inheritance of parentally-acquired information.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian fission challenges the notion of distinct generations, raising questions about inheritance.

chunks.text: Planarian regeneration involves long-range cell communication, similar to generational information transfer, highlighting the parallel between spatial and temporal pattern control.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration involves long-range cell communication, paralleling the temporal information transfer in generational inheritance.

chunks.text: Planarian neoblasts, crucial for regeneration, exhibit genetic diversity and interact with surrounding cells, raising questions about the source of regeneration information and the role of somatic cells in phenotype determination.
chunks.chunk_summary: Genetically diverse planarian neoblasts interact with surrounding cells, raising questions about the source of regeneration information and somatic cell influence.

chunks.text: Asymmetric fission in planaria could lead to unequal inheritance of epigenetic marks, potentially creating phenotypic differences between regenerating individuals and impacting clonality.
chunks.chunk_summary: Asymmetric fission may result in unequal epigenetic inheritance, leading to phenotypic differences between planarian clones.

chunks.text: Several mechanisms could contribute to asymmetry after planarian fission, including genetic diversity in neoblasts, biochemical gradients, epigenetic modifications, and somatic cell influence on neoblasts.
chunks.chunk_summary: Genetic diversity, biochemical gradients, epigenetics, and somatic cell influence are potential mechanisms contributing to asymmetry after planarian fission.

chunks.text: Genetically distinct neoblasts and surrounding cells contribute to planarian regeneration, potentially influencing the genetics of asexually reproducing planarians and requiring consideration for genetic editing.
chunks.section: Genetic diversity in the progenitor cell population
chunks.chunk_summary: Genetic mosaicism in planarian neoblasts and surrounding cells can influence the genetics of asexually reproducing planarians.

chunks.text: Biochemical gradients and local environments influence planarian regeneration, potentially contributing to long-term phenotypic differences between fragments through positive feedback processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biochemical gradients can influence planarian regeneration and contribute to long-term phenotypic differences.

chunks.text: Epigenetic mechanisms, including small RNAs and chromatin modifications, are being explored in planaria, with the potential to mediate asymmetry following fission and contribute to transgenerational gene regulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Epigenetic mechanisms, such as small RNAs and chromatin modifications, may mediate asymmetry and transgenerational gene regulation in planaria.

chunks.text: Somatic cells, through gap junctional coupling and neural inputs, influence neoblast function and potentially contribute to breaching the Weismann barrier in planaria, impacting phenotype determination.
chunks.chunk_summary: Somatic cells influence neoblast function and may breach the Weismann barrier in planaria, impacting phenotype determination.

chunks.text: Bioelectric circuits, involving ion channels and gap junctions, play a crucial role in pattern formation during development and regeneration, influencing cell behavior and potentially storing physiological experience.
chunks.section: Bioelectric circuits and somatic pattern memory
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric circuits regulate pattern formation and may store physiological experience in various tissues.

chunks.text: Planarian brains exhibit complex learning and memory, raising the possibility that neuronally encoded memories can survive decapitation and influence regeneration, potentially impacting anatomical structure.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian brains can store complex memories that may survive decapitation and influence regeneration, potentially affecting anatomical structure.

chunks.text: Hypothetical scenarios are presented to explore the relationship between regenerating planarian fragments, considering the potential for epigenetic differences, memory retention, and the impact on generational definitions.
chunks.section: Asymmetric retention of neuronally encoded memory
chunks.chunk_summary: Hypothetical scenarios explore the relationship between regenerating planarian fragments, considering epigenetic differences and memory retention.

chunks.text: Investigating the molecular and biophysical differences between fragments from one-headed and two-headed planaria can reveal how anatomical history influences regeneration outcomes.
chunks.section: Maintenance of bioelectric gradients derived from fragment tissue
chunks.chunk_summary: Analyzing molecular and biophysical differences between fragments can reveal how anatomical history influences regeneration.

chunks.text: Optimizing training protocols and assessing memory persistence in different planarian fragments can help understand how and where memory is stored outside the brain during regeneration.
chunks.section: Maintenance of behavioral memories across regenerative reproduction
chunks.chunk_summary: Optimizing training and assessing memory persistence can elucidate how and where memory is stored outside the brain during regeneration.

chunks.text: Asymmetric fission in planaria and other organisms can generate variation, challenging traditional views of evolution and offering potential applications in regenerative medicine and bioengineering.
chunks.chunk_summary: Asymmetric fission can generate variation, challenging traditional evolutionary views and offering applications in regenerative medicine.
